_children.body: Let us consider two solenoids $$A$$ and $$B$$, made from same magnetic material of relative permeability $$\mu_r$$ and equal area of cross-section. Length of $$A$$ is twice that of $$B$$ and the number of turns per unit length in $$A$$ is half that of $$B$$. The ratio of self inductances of the two solenoids, $$L_A: L_B$$ is
_children.explanation: $$\begin{aligned} & L=\mu_0 \mu_r \times n \times A \times N \\ & L=\mu_0 \mu_r n \times A \times \frac{N}{I} \times I \\ & L=\mu_0 \mu_r \times n^2 \times A \times I \Rightarrow L \propto n^2 I \\ & \Rightarrow \frac{L_A}{L_B}=\frac{n_A^2}{n_B^2} \times \frac{I_A}{I_B} \\ & \Rightarrow \frac{L_A}{L_B}=\frac{1}{4} \times 2=\frac{1}{2} \end{aligned}$$

_children.body:
The magnetic flux linked to a circular coil of radius R is

$$\phi = 2{t^3} + 4{t^2} + 2t + 5$$ Wb

The magnitude of induced emf in the coil at t = 5 s is
_children.explanation:
Given magnetic flux is

$$\phi = 2{t^3} + 4{t^2} + 2t + 5$$

Induced emf is given by

$$\varepsilon = {{ - d\phi } \over {dt}} = {{ - d} \over {dt}}(2{t^3} + 4{t^2} + 2t + 5)$$

$$|\varepsilon | = 6{t^2} + 8t + 2$$

At $$t = 5$$ s,

$$|\varepsilon | = 6 \times 25 + 8 \times 5 + 2$$

$$ = 150 + 40 + 2$$

$$ = 192$$ V

_children.body: A 800 turn coil of effective area 0.05 m<sup>2</sup> is kept.  perpendicular to a magnetic filed 5 × 10<sup>–5</sup> T. When the plane of the coil is rotated by 90<sup>o</sup> around any of its coplanar axis in 0.1 s, the emf induced in the coil will be :
_children.explanation:
Given N = 800, A = 0.05 m2 , B = 5 × 10–5 T

$$\Delta $$t = 0.15 s

We know, e = $$ - {{\left( {{\phi _f} - {\phi _i}} \right)} \over {\Delta t}}$$

= $$ - {{\left( {0 - NBA} \right)} \over {\Delta t}}$$

= $${{800 \times 5 \times {{10}^{ - 5}} \times 5 \times {{10}^{ - 2}}} \over {0.1}}$$

= 0.02 V

_children.body: A long solenoid of diameter 0.1 m has 2 $$ \times $$ 10<sup>4</sup> turns per meter. At the centre of the solenoid, a coil of 100 turns and radius 0.01 m is placed with its axis coinciding with the solenoid axis. The current in the solenoid reduces at a constant rate to 0 A from 4 A in 0.05 s. If the resistance of the coil is 10 $$\pi $$<sup>2</sup> $$\Omega $$, the total charge flowing through the coil during this time is

A long solenoid has 1000 turns. When a current of 4 A flows through it, the magnetic flux linked with each turn of the solenoid is 4 $$ \times \,{10^{ - 3}}$$ Wb.  The self-inductance of the solenoid is
_children.explanation:
Total flux linked with the solenoid, $$\phi $$ = N$$\phi $$0

= 1000 $$ \times $$ 4 $$ \times $$ 10-3 Wb = 4 Wb

$$ \therefore $$ Self-inductance of solenoid

L = $${\phi \over I} = {4 \over 4}$$ = 1 H

_children.body: A current of 2.5 A flows through a coil of inductance 5 H. The magnetic flux linked with the coil is
_children.explanation:
Here, I = 2.5 A, L = 5 H

Magnetic flux linked with the coil is

$$\phi $$B = LI = (5 H)(2.5 A) = 12.5 Wb

_children.body:
A coil of resistance 400 $$\Omega $$ is placed in a magnetic field. If the magnetic flux $$\phi $$ (Wb) linked with the coil varies with time t (sec) as $$\phi = 50{t^2} + 4$$.

The current in the coil at t = 2 sec is
_children.explanation:
According, to Faraday’s law of induction

Induced e.m.f, $$\varepsilon = - {{d\phi } \over {dt}}$$ = -(100t)

Induced current i at t = 2 sec.

= $$\left| {{\varepsilon \over R}} \right| = + {{100 \times 2} \over {400}}$$ = +0.5 A

_children.body: A conducting circular loop is placed in a uniform magnetic field, B = 0.025 T with its plane perpendicular to the loop. The radius of the loop is made to shrink at a constant rate of 1 mm s<sup>$$-$$1</sup>. The induced emf when the radius is 2 cm, is
_children.explanation:
Constant rate at which radius of the loop shrinks

$${{dr} \over {dt}} = 1 \times {10^{-3}}$$ m s-1

Magnetic flux linked with the loop is

$$\phi $$ = BAcos$$\phi $$ = B($$\pi $$r2)cos0o = B$$\pi $$r2

The magnitude of the induced emf is

|e| = $${{d\phi } \over {dt}} = {d \over {dt}}\left( {B\pi {r^2}} \right) = B\pi 2r{{dr} \over {dt}}$$

= 0.025 $$ \times $$ $$\pi $$ $$ \times $$ 2 $$ \times $$ 2 $$ \times $$ 10-2 $$ \times $$ 1 $$ \times $$ 10-3

= $$\pi $$ $$ \times $$ 10-6 V

= $$\pi \mu V$$

_children.body: A rectangular, a square, a circular and an elliptical loop, all in the (x-y) plane, are moving out of a uniform magnetic field with a constant velocity. $$\overrightarrow V  = v\widehat i$$. The magnetic field is directed along the negative z axis direction. The induced emf, during the passes of these loops, out of the field region, will not remain constant for

options.value: The circular and the elliptical loops
the rectangular, circular and elliptical loops

_children.explanation: Once a rectangular loop or a square loop is being drawn out of the field, the rate of cutting the lines of field will be a constant for a square and rectangle, but not for circular or elliptical areas.

_children.body: A conducting circular loop is placed in a uniform magnetic field 0.04 T with its plane perpendicular to the magnetic field. The radius of the loop starts shrinking at 2 mm/s. The induced emf in the loop when the radius is 2 cm is
_children.explanation:
Constant rate at which radius of the loop shrinks

$${{dr} \over {dt}} = 2 \times {10^{-3}}$$ m s-1

Magnetic flux linked with the loop is

$$\phi $$ = BAcos$$\phi $$ = B($$\pi $$r2)cos0o = B$$\pi $$r2

The magnitude of the induced emf is

|e| = $${{d\phi } \over {dt}} = {d \over {dt}}\left( {B\pi {r^2}} \right) = B\pi 2r{{dr} \over {dt}}$$

= 0.04 $$ \times $$ $$\pi $$ $$ \times $$ 2 $$ \times $$ 2 $$ \times $$ 10-2 $$ \times $$ 2 $$ \times $$ 10-3

= 3.2$$\pi $$ $$ \times $$ 10-6 V

= 3.2$$\pi \mu V$$

_children.body: A long solenoid has 500 turns. When a current of 2 ampere is passed through it, the resulting magnetic flux linked with each turn of the solenoid is 4 $$ \times $$ 10<sup>$$-$$3</sup> Wb. The self-inductance of the solenoid is
_children.explanation:
Total number of turns in the solenoid,

N = 500 Current, I = 2A.

Magnetic flux linked with each turn = 4 × 10–3 Wb

Self inductance of coil :

L = $${{N\phi } \over I} = {{500 \times 4 \times {{10}^3}} \over 2}$$ = 1 H

_children.body: A circular disc of radius 0.2 meter is placed in a uniform magnetic field of induction $${1 \over \pi }\left( {{{Wb} \over {{m^2}}}} \right)$$ in such a way that its axis makes an angle of 60<sup>o</sup> with $$\overrightarrow B .$$ The magnetic flux linked with the disc is
_children.explanation:
Given B = $${1 \over \pi }\left( {{{Wb} \over {{m^2}}}} \right)$$

$$\theta $$ = 60o

Area normal to the plane of the disc

= $$\pi $$r2 cos60o = $${{\pi {r^2}} \over 2}$$

Flux = B × normal area

= $${{0.02 \times 0.02} \over 2}$$ = 0.02 Wb

_children.body: Two coils of self inductance 2 mH and 8 mH are placed so close together that the effective flux in one coil is completely linked with the other. The mutual inductance between these coils is
_children.explanation:
Mutual inductance is given as,

M = K$$\sqrt {{L_1} \times {L_2}} $$

Now given, K = 1, L1 = 2 mH, L2 = 8 mH

$$ \therefore $$ M = $$1 \times \sqrt {2 \times 8} $$ = 4 mH

_children.body: The magnetic flux through a circuit of resistance R changes by an amount $$\Delta $$$$\phi $$ in a time $$\Delta $$t. Then the total quantity of electric charge Q that passes any point in the circuit during the time $$\Delta $$t is represented by
_children.explanation:
$${{\Delta \phi } \over {\Delta t}}$$ = E = iR

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $${\Delta \phi = \left( {i\Delta t} \right)R}$$ = QR

$$ \Rightarrow $$ Q = $$ {{\Delta \phi } \over R}$$

_children.body: For a coil having L = 2 mH, current flow through it is $$I = {t^2}{e^{ - t}}$$ then, the time at which emf become zero
_children.explanation:
Given, $$I = {t^2}{e^{ - t}}$$

So, $${{dI} \over {dt}} = 2t{e^{ - t}} - {t^2}{e^{ - t}}$$

$$\left| \varepsilon \right| = L{{dI} \over {dt}}$$

here emf is zero when $${{dI} \over {dt}}$$ = 0

$$ \therefore $$ $$2t{e^{ - t}} - {t^2}{e^{ - t}}$$ = 0

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $$2t{e^{ - t}} = {t^2}{e^{ - t}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $$t{e^{ - t}}\left( {t - 2} \right)$$ = 0

As t $$ \ne $$ $$\infty $$, t $$ \ne $$ 0

$$ \therefore $$ t = 2 sec
